pages.text: Dimensions are accessible realms within a world characterized by a way of generation, biomes and structures, and other things unique to one dimension. $(br2)$(thing)Players$() can explore and discover various dimensions in Minecraft, typically through the use of portals.

$(br2)The daylight cycle and weather may work differently or not exist in different dimensions, as well as respawn points (such as beds and respawn anchors) and travel speed. $(br2)Other dimensions can be access with portals.

pages.title: The Overworld
pages.text: The Overworld is the primary dimension in Minecraft. It has a wide variety of unique biomes to explore, and is easily the most diverse of the dimensions.   $(br) $(li)large biome variation $(li)Lage mob variation $(li)oceans of water $(li)daylight circle $(li)weather $(li)384 block world height

pages.title: The Nether
pages.text: The Nether is a hostile dimension containing huge lava oceans. The ground consists of mainly $(item)Netherrack$() and is considered as the underworld of the game. $(br) $(li)chaotic, messy, dangerous, cave-like terrain $(li)oceans of lava $(li)ceiling of $(item)Bedrock$() $(li)increased travel speed $(li)using a charged $(item)Respawn Anchor$() sets spawn point $(li)256 block world height

pages.title: The End
pages.text: The End is a space-like dimension with floating $(item)End Stone$() islands. It's a barren environment, but it's the only place where some of the most unique and useful items in the game can be obtained $(br) $(li)direct access to the void $(li)home of the Ender Dragon $(li)floating islands of $(item)End Stone$() $(li)big pillars of $(item)Obsidian$() $(li)256 block world height
